## Boolean Functions

<p>

At the very lowest level, computer circuitry is made of wires, and each wire is either on or off. So the only operations that can be performed at that lowest level are those that <em>operate on single-bit values</em> (just ones and zeros, that is, just ons and offs). These are called <em>logical (or Boolean) functions</em>. (They're predicates, because their range is Booleans, but these are special in that their <em>domain</em> is also Booleans.) There are three Boolean functions in the Operators palette:<br /> <img src="/img/prog/Booleans.png" title="and, or, not blocks" alt="and, or, not blocks" class="indent"/><br />

::: comment
AAP-2.F.5, AAP-2.F.1
:::

Notice that both the blocks themselves and the input slots in the blocks are hexagonal. Boolean functions take Boolean values (<code>True</code> or <code>False</code>) as inputs and report a new Boolean value as output. When you use Boolean functions in a program, though, the inputs will usually be expressions such as <img src="/img/2-complexity/var=3.png" title="variable = 3" alt="variable = 3"/>.

</p>

<p>

The <code>and</code> and <code>not</code> blocks work exactly the way you'd expect from the meanings of those words in English:

<ul>

::: comment
AAP-2.F.3
:::

<li><img src="/img/2-complexity/true-and-true.png" title="(true) and (true)" alt="(true) and (true)"/> reports <code>true</code>, and any other combination of inputs reports <code>false</code>.</li>

::: comment
AAP-2.F.2
:::

<li><img src="/img/blocks/not.png" title="not ()" alt="not ()"/> reports the opposite of whichever input value you use.</li>

</ul>

::: comment
AAP-2.F.4
:::

But <code>or</code> is a little different in computer science. In English, the word "or" has two different meanings:

<ul>

<li><strong>Either but not both:</strong> such as "Let's check whether it will be rainy or sunny tomorrow." In computer science, this is called <em>exclusive or</em> because one option excludes the other.</li>

<li><strong>Either or both:</strong> such as "Ask your teacher if you have any questions or if you need help." This is called <em>inclusive or</em> because it's possible for both options to be included.</li>

</ul>

</p>

</ol>
:::

TG (for answer key): i) The <code>and</code> function can be represented as TFFF; ii-v) Answers will vary for parts ii and iii. The following table lists the 16 (part iv) possible two-input Boolean operators and their usefulness. The goal is for students to <em>think about usefulness</em>---not for them to accurately categorize each of the functions or even to learn the logic of each one. Unless you have a background in logic or computer science, even you (as teacher with the answer key) are likely to find some of these take a bit of thinking to wrap your mind around. 31b8e172-b470-440e-83d8-e6b185028602::31b8e172-b470-440e-83d8-e6b185028602 vi) There are 256 three-input Boolean operators because there are eight combinations of inputs for a three-input Boolean operator and each of those combinations could report one of two values (T or F): [2\^8=256]{.katex}. (For comparison, there are 16 two-input Boolean operators because there are four combinations of inputs for a two-input operator and each can report one of two values (T or F): [2\^4=16]{.katex}.)
:::

<ol type="A">

<li>

Because there are only two Boolean values (<code>true</code> and <code>false</code>), there are only four combinations of inputs for a two-input Boolean operator. Here are the four combinations shown with the <code>or</code> operator:<br /> <img src="/img/2-complexity/or-t-t.png" alt="or (true) (true)" class="indent"/><br /> <img src="/img/2-complexity/or-t-f.png" alt="or (true) (false)" class="indent"/><br /> <img src="/img/2-complexity/or-f-t.png" alt="or (false) (true)" class="indent"/><br /> <img src="/img/2-complexity/or-f-f.png" alt="or (false) (false)" class="indent"/>

<ol style="list-style-type: lower-roman">

<li>With <code>or</code>, the four combinations report <code>true</code>, <code>true</code>, <code>true</code>, and <code>false</code> in that order. (Check for yourself that this is true.) So, you can represent the <code>or</code> function as TTTF (using T and F as abbreviations for <code>true</code> and <code>false</code>). What are the four letters for the <code>and</code> function? (Assume the same ordering of the inputs: TT, TF, FT, and FF as shown above with <code>or</code>.)</li>

<li>

Make up another set of four letters (such as TFTF), and build a predicate function with that behavior. Describe how the function behaves.

::: endnote
<a href="#hint-TFTF" data-bs-toggle="collapse" title="Click to see an example showing and describing the behavior of TFTF.">Click to see an example showing and describing the behavior of TFTF.</a>

::: {#hint-TFTF .collapse}
<img src="/img/2-complexity/TFTF-TT-reporting.png" title="(true) TFTF (true) reporting true" alt="(true) TFTF (true) reporting true" class="indent"/><br /> <img src="/img/2-complexity/TFTF-TF-reporting.png" title="(true) TFTF (false) reporting true" alt="(true) TFTF (false) reporting true" class="indent"/><br /> <img src="/img/2-complexity/TFTF-FT-reporting.png" title="(false) TFTF (true) reporting true" alt="(false) TFTF (true) reporting true" class="indent"/><br /> <img src="/img/2-complexity/TFTF-FF-reporting.png" title="(false) TFTF (false) reporting false" alt="(false) TFTF (false) reporting false" class="indent"/> The TFTF function reports true whenever the second input is true no matter what the first input is. It's not a useful function because you could just use the second input as the predicate instead of building this predicate function.
:::
:::

</li>

Which of the possible two-input Boolean operators do you think would be useful? Discuss why.</li>
